content.content: Congenital heart defects are the most common birth defect and leading cause of infant deaths especially during the first 27 days of life.[^166][^165] Critical Congenital Heart Disease (CCHD) is a severe form of congenital heart disease. One of four babies born with a congenital heart defect has CCHD.[^166][^167][^168][^165] About 30% of CCHD deaths are from a missed or a late diagnosis.[^170] Pulse oximetry is the screening test for CCHD[^171][^172]. This painless, non-invasive test tells how much oxygen is in the baby’s blood. It is done when the baby is 24 hour old or before discharge from the hospital.[^171][^172] If the baby's pulse oximetry screening result is less than 90% in both the right hand & foot, follow-up testing is done.[^172] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/GZfdM93ALZo Embedded content: https://youtu.be/pdtVk3hqmBM [5 Things You Need to Know About Congenital Heart Disease from the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/heartdefects/documents/5ThingsCHD.pdf) [Screening for Critical Congenital Heart Disease from the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/heartdefects/documents/ncbddd_birth-defects_cchd-newborn-screening.pdf) [Newborn Screening Information from Baby's First Test](http://www.babysfirsttest.org) [Tips to Survive Your Child's Hospital Stay from Parents.com](http://www.parents.com/parenting/better-parenting/advice/tips-to-survive-your-childs-hospital-stay/) [^165]: Hoffman J, Kaplan S.
